title: Pandora
summary: In Greek mythology, Pandora (Greek: Πανδώρα,  derived from πᾶν, pān, i.e. "all" and δῶρον, dōron, i.e. "gift", thus  "the all-endowed", "all-gifted" or "all-giving")[1] was the first human woman created by Hephaestus on the instructions of Zeus.[2][3] As Hesiod related it, each god cooperated by giving her unique gifts. Her other name—inscribed against her figure on a white-ground kylix in the British Museum[4]—is Anesidora (Ancient Greek: Ἀνησιδώρα), "she who sends up gifts"[5] (up implying "from below" within the earth).
